description: Of unknown origin. Perhaps an alteration of fawny (“gilt brass ring used by swindlers”) (1781), from Irish fáinne (“ring”).

entries.meaning: (informal) Fraudulent; fake; having a misleading appearance.
examples: A good jeweler should be able to tell a real stone from a phony one.

entries.meaning: (informal) A person who assumes an identity or quality other than their own.
examples: He claims to be a doctor, but he's nothing but a fast-talking phony.

entries.meaning: (informal) A person who professes beliefs or opinions that they do not hold.
examples: Synonyms: faker, dissembler, pretender, fake; see also Thesaurus:deceiver
He's such a phony, he doesn't believe half of what he says.
One name was a phony, but the other was the true name. The clerk remembered the man who had filed the tags since he acquired two sets of plates with different names.

verbs.description: phony (third-person singular simple present phonies, present participle phonying, simple past and past participle phonied)
